author: jgm
content:
Following on from the conversation around seeing more orphans in the first few slots of an epoch, I gathered data from my node about the delay between start of a slot and the block for that slot arriving.  I'm ignoring anything above 12s for now (there are some out-of-order blocks that turn up 15-20 minutes after they are expected!).

The interesting part of the plot is in the bottom left, where you can see very few blocks arrive in the first second after epoch transitions.

author: jgm
content: And a zoom in on the interesting bit.

author: barnabemonnot
content: <@144468805697929216> very interesting! would you be ok with sharing the data?

author: jgm
content:
Sure.  This is the raw data as `(slot,slot in epoch,gap between slot start time and receiving block in ms)`.

There are some interesting items in there, like some blocks being received for slots before the slot starts (clock skew, I'd imagine) and various blocks being received well out of their slot (which could be my node missing the block first time around, and then requesting it when it's trying to reconcile later state, or just the block being really late).

author: jgm
content: So a bit of filtering probably required, depending on what you're looking for

author: barnabemonnot
content: thank you! i am curious to check more clearly how it is distributed, i can't really tell from the line dots, although they really show the scattering for slot 0

Most clients could agree on the deposit root most of the time, but block roots were often all over the place which hindered getting over the 50% threshold for agreement surprisingly often. I'll see if I can run some numbers for Medalla over the weekend.

author: jgm
content:
> thank you! i am curious to check more clearly how it is distributed, i can't really tell from the line dots, although they really show the scattering for slot 0
Yeah I started out looking for a trend, hence the zoomed-out view.  The only thing that jumps out visually is that slot 0 delays start much later and are much more spread out, but if you find anything else with better analysis it would be great to hear about it.
